com.flyingspaniel.xen
Class Xen

java.lang.Object
  com.flyingspaniel.xen.Xen

public class Xen
extends Object

A simple and sane XML implementation using Java Collections, Generics, and varargs. A Xen ("XML Element Node") roughly corresponds to a Element and a groovy.util.Node.
There are not the 10 other types of nodes and 25 Subinterfaces from Node

  • Attributes are kept in a Map<String,String>
  • text is kept in a single String (always normalized)
  • child Elements (other Xen) are kept in a List<Xen>
If using namespaces, the name of an elementXP is always qualified name. The URI is forgotten. e.g. <w:border> <w:border/> has a name of "w:border". There are no Comments, EntityReferences, etc. etc. If you need these don't use Xen. However, all Xens have a field props, which is a Map, which might be useful for small additions.

Combined with Xpath, Xen allows for "XPath-like" selection and movement. Note that this XPath-like syntax is very similar to Groovy's XMLSlurper syntax if you replace "." with a "/". e.g.
Where Groovy might use root.records.car[0].@make
Xen would use root.attributeXP("records/car[1]/@make"); // note 1 based offset

Since:
Copyright (c) 2014 by Morgan Conrad

text

public String text()
Get text from this Xen. Text is always "normalized" (combined into one single String A loose replacement for org.w3c.dom.Node.getTextContent() and groovy.util.Node.text(), but DOES NOT INCLUDE text from children

Returns:
never-null, may be empty

text

public String text(boolean includeChildren)
Get text from this Xen, plus, possibly, all children. Breadth first. So similar to org.w3c.dom.getTextContent and groovy.util.Node.text().

Parameters:
includeChildren -
Returns:
never null

Returns:
null if none found
Throws:
DOMException - if multiple matches

attributes

public Map<String,String> attributes()
Return all the Attributes as a modifiable Map. Use to implement other functionality in Node. For example 
     void Node.removeAttribute(String name) { attributes().remove(name); }

Returns:
Map
